awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Conservation Science at Zoo Miami
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Zoo Miami, in partnership with Florida International University, located in Miami, FL, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2020- 2022.  The REU Site, focused on conservation science, includes projects in field conservation (population biology, habitat ecology, invasive species biology, and global change ecology) and management of captive populations (wildlife disease biology, wildlife nutrition, animal psychology, animal behavior, reproductive physiology). Students will conduct closely mentored but independent research projects under the guidance of Zoo scientists and university-based researchers. Students will gain valuable skills in experimental design and data collection, written and oral communication, data management and data analysis, and reading and interpreting scientific literature. Students will gain exposure to STEM-related careers both within and outside of academia. In addition, students will learn STEM education in informal settings.

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students will be trained in the program over the 3 year period of the grant. This program focuses on advancing diversity and participation of underrepresented groups in STEM. At least 50% of students will come from groups underrepresented in STEM, and at least 70% of students will come from colleges and universities with limited research opportunities, including community colleges. Students will engage in every part of the research process and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. A common web-based assessment tool (used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure) will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students are expected to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting https://www.zoomiami.org/reu_program, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Steven Whitfield at steven.whitfield@miamidade.gov) or the co-PI (Dr. Elizabeth Anderson at epanders@fiu.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This REU Site award to Zoo Miami, in collaboration with Florida International University, located in Miami, FL, ran for three years (2021, 2022, and 2023). The science theme focused on conservation biology- including projects in situ conservation (population biology, habitat ecology, invasive species biology, urban ecology), ex situ conservation (wildlife health, animal cognition, reproductive physiology, animal behavior), and conservation education (informal STEM learning, formal STEM learning, conservation psychology).

During this 10-week summer research program, students were paired with one or more mentors to conduct guided but independent research. Students developed science communication skills through the development of proposal presentations, poster presentations, standard 12-minute oral presentations, and written manuscripts. Core skills trainings for students included scientific ethics, data management, data analysis, data visualization, scientific writing, and scientific presentations. Local field trips and guest lectures helped tie together the theme of conservation science and to immerse students in south Florida environments.

This program trained 30 undergraduate students from core NSF support, four high school teachers through two NSF RET supplements, one postbaccalaureate through a NSF REPS supplement, and one undergraduate through external support (a DACA recipient ineligible for NSF support). This program supported high levels of participation from underrepresented minorities, including 11 African American undergraduates and 14 Hispanic or Latino undergraduates. More than 50% of undergraduate participants attended universities with limited opportunities for research.

This REU site was the first and only REU Site based in a zoo environment, and to our knowledge was the only funded, cohort-based training program for undergraduates in zoo conservation science within the US. The zoo environment allowed students to gain exposure to a broad range of STEM careers, including academic biologists, wildlife managers, wildlife veterinarians, and STEM educators. This program addressed a national-level gap in zoo-based conservation science training programs. The REU site received 1071 applications for 30 positions across three program years, indicating high levels of interest in zoo-based conservation science programs that are well beyond the capacity of a single zoo-based program to fulfill.

Student evaluations reported that students appreciated the zoo-based environment as unique and scientifically-engaging environment. They appreciated the support of Zoo Miami and Florida International University, the location of Miami for hosting an REU program, and program trainings and field trips as positive aspects of the program. Several students have presented their research at local or national conferences, and several students have continued their careers in graduate programs or veterinary programs.
